pullRequest.body:
This is the most basic file of the theory of fibred categories developed here: https://github.com/sinhp/LeanFibredCategories/tree/master


---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: Why not call it `Fiber`? I personally think of the Fibonacci function first when I hear "Fib"
@adri326 Good call. will change to `Fiber` now.

@adri326 Currently getting the error "continuous integration / Check all files imported (push)". 

I'm not sure what this means and how I can resolve it?

The CI is unhappy, yeah. It's mainly complaining about:
- your `simp`s are not normalizing (if `simp` can prove a statement directly then that statement shouldn't be marked as `@[simp]`, for instance)
- in general, if you have two arguments of the form `(x : X) (p : f x)`, then you should mark the first one as optional
- you're missing some documentation before your `def`s
- the error you mentionned means that your new file, `Mathlib.Data.Fiber`, isn't imported in the main `Mathlib.lean`; there is a command that will do this for you in the README, but you can also just apply the changes that you can see in the linter's details

> The CI is unhappy, yeah. It's mainly complaining about:
> 
> * your `simp`s are not normalizing (if `simp` can prove a statement directly then that statement shouldn't be marked as `@[simp]`, for instance)
> * in general, if you have two arguments of the form `(x : X) (p : f x)`, then you should mark the first one as optional
> * you're missing some documentation before your `def`s
> * the error you mentionned means that your new file, `Mathlib.Data.Fiber`, isn't imported in the main `Mathlib.lean`; there is a command that will do this for you in the README, but you can also just apply the changes that you can see in the linter's details

that was helpful, thanks. It now builds. the only error is the last one which you addressed, and I just executed 
```
find Mathlib -name "*.lean" | env LC_ALL=C sort | sed 's/\.lean//;s,/,.,g;s/^/import /' > Mathlib.lean
```
following the README file.

Looks clean! Although one thing that the linter doesn't currently catch is [indentation](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html#structuring-definitions-and-theorems), you'll want to have the proof bodies be indented by 2 spaces, in particular

> Looks clean! Although one thing that the linter doesn't currently catch is [indentation](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html#structuring-definitions-and-theorems), you'll want to have the proof bodies be indented by 2 spaces, in particular

helpful link, thanks!

I am not completely sure that we have a need for a new definition. The type you define is definitionally equal to the preimage of a singleton:
```lean
example {X S : Type*} (f : X → S) (s : S) : f ⁻¹' {s} = { x : X // f x = s} := rfl
```
Then, an abbrev in the `Functor` namespace, like `Functor.Fibre` would presumably be more appropriate.

More importantly, I am also worried that there are different people working on the same subject https://github.com/Paul-Lez/Stacks-project and I believe that there should be some discussion (e.g. on Zulip) and coordination in order to get a consistent design.

Hi @joelriou. Thanks for sharing the other parallel project; I was not aware of it. 

Let me address your concerns: 
1. It is possible to have a file `Functor.Fiber` instead of `Data.Fiber`, which defines the fibers of a functor directly. Note that in https://github.com/sinhp/LeanFibredCategories/blob/0f67f10b0fd7ec8df3a377947f3443638b380367/LeanFibredCategories/Fiber.lean#L82
I define the fiber of a functor as the fiber of its object function. 

I discussed this with @jcommelin and we thought it is perhaps better to define `Fiber` for a map and use it to define to the fiber of a functor as it is more general this way and potentially might be useful in other places than just category theory. Also, `f ⁻¹' {s}` is really a subset which then gets coerced to a type, but `Fiber` is a directly a type and this is preferred (?). 

2. Regarding the other formalization, would be happy to open a PR topic on Zulip to discuss the two projects to coordinate. Let me note that based on studying the link you sent, it seems the two projects develop different ways to formalize the notion of fibration. In my formalization, I was inspired by the style of display categories (see `BasedLift` structure in https://github.com/sinhp/LeanFibredCategories/blob/0f67f10b0fd7ec8df3a377947f3443638b380367/LeanFibredCategories/CartesianLift.lean#L29 
and 
https://github.com/sinhp/LeanFibredCategories/blob/0f67f10b0fd7ec8df3a377947f3443638b380367/LeanFibredCategories/CartesianLift.lean#L43
)
which scales well as we know from other formalizations in other proof assistants. As tests, I have formalized the cases of codomain fibration and discrete fibrations as examples of cartesian (i.e. Grothendieck) fibrations. 

https://github.com/sinhp/LeanFibredCategories/blob/master/LeanFibredCategories/GrothendieckFibration.lean
https://github.com/sinhp/LeanFibredCategories/blob/master/LeanFibredCategories/CodFibration.lean
https://github.com/sinhp/LeanFibredCategories/blob/master/LeanFibredCategories/DiscreteFibration.lean

And finally, the display-category inspired formalization allows us to define Street fibrations by changing a parameter in Grothendieck fibration, namely changing `eqToHom` to `eqToIso`! This makes it the formalization modular and unifies the theory of Grothendieck and Street fibrations.

The injectivity of `eqRebase` trivially follows from the following statement, which you might find useful too:

```
@[simp]
theorem coe_eqRebase (f : Fiber P c) (eq : c = d) : (eqRebase f eq : E) = f.1 := rfl
```

If you import `Mathlib.Data.Subtype`, then you can simply write
```
lemma coe_inj (x y : Fiber P c) : (x : E) = y ↔ x = y := Subtype.coe_inj
```
great, I had it at some point, and reverted back to the longer form. but this makes more sense. 👍
I would call this one `cast`, since that seems to be the common name for this kind of operation
I wonder if this is a special case and the proof can be special case of something about `cast`?

about renaming to `cast`, this is how `cast` is defined in Prelude: 

```
@[macro_inline] def cast {α β : Sort u} (h : Eq α β) (a : α) : β :=
  h.rec a
```
It seems that `cast` transports terms across a type equality, whereas in `eqRebase` we transport across equality of terms in the base. So, I am not sure if this is in line with the philosophy of `cast`?

I was thinking more in terms of how `Fin.cast` is defined: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Std/Data/Fin/Basic.html#Fin.cast

This is only a suggestion, though :)
Brilliant. :) Just changed it to `cast`.

`simp` is able to solve this directly using https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Subtype.html#Subtype.coe_eta

The name should also mention your `eqRebase`/`cast` operation, so something like `cast_coe_tauto` (same with `coe_tauto'`).

pullRequest.title: feat: the type `Fib` of fibre of a function at a point
